requirement_groups.description: Complete all requirements for Bachelor of Arts

requirement_groups.title: Arts elective units
requirement_groups.description: You must complete 24 credit points of Arts elective units which can be combined into a minor of study different to the chosen major from Part A and with no more than 12 credit points at Level 1.

requirement_groups.title: Global immersion
requirement_groups.description:
You may complete the following units or any of the Arts study tours or semester length programs by submitting an enquiry to Monash Connect. Please note, study tours must be offered by the Faculty of Arts in order to be counted as Professional Futures units.

Please visit https://www.monash.edu/arts/learning-abroad/global-study-tours for more information.

requirement_groups.title: Professional Futures
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 24 credit points from the units in the following Professional Futures domains.

Note: If you are enrolled in the double degree D3002 Bachelor of Education (Honours) in Secondary Education and Bachelor of Arts, you must complete 12 credit points of units from the Professional Futures domains and the remaining 12 credit points should be selected from level 1, 2 or 3 Arts' elective units.

For your discipline studies in the double degree secondary education specialisation, you must complete a Victorian Institute of Teaching minor study in one secondary teaching area. The minor study must consist of four units, with no more than two units at first year level. Space for the minor study units will come from elective unit allocations on the course map. Approved disciplines can be found on the secondary specialist areas page.
.

requirement_groups.title: Part B. Arts specified study
requirement_groups.description: You must complete 24 credit points of Arts elective units and 24 credit points of units from the Professional Futures domains.

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description:
To satisfy the requirements of the Bachelor of Arts you must complete 144 credit points as specified in the course requirements, including:

- a maximum of 60 credit points at Level 1 and,
- a minimum of 36 credit points at Level 3, of which at least 24 credit points must be Arts units.

It is recommended that you keep your options open in your first year by taking a sequence of units in at least two different areas of study that offer majors within Arts.

You may use your Arts electives in Part B. and C. to complete a double major, but please note that no more than two units (12 credit points) can normally be credited towards two majors. Double majors are only available for students undertaking the single degree.

requirement_groups.title: Part C. Free elective study
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 48 credit points of free electives from across the university, provided you satisfy the unit rules. Elective units may be chosen from units available in the Bachelor of Arts course to complete a second major or minor(s) from the course. The units may be at any level ensuring that the course rules are satisfied for the Bachelor of Arts. At most, two Level 1 units may be counted towards two majors or a major and a minor.

In double degree courses, some units required for the other degree are credited as electives towards the Arts degree.

You are encouraged to take an internship as an elective unit for an opportunity to apply coursework to real world situations and develop workplace skills.

You can enrich your degree by using some of your free electives to take a study tour, field trip or exchange opportunity. You can also use this space to hone your academic and professional skills with an internship or a range of practical units. See Arts enrichment https://www.monash.edu/students/handbooks/faculty-info/undergrad/arts/enrichment-units and Monash Intercultural Lab https://www.monash.edu/students/handbooks/faculty-info/undergrad/arts/monash-intercultural-lab-units lists of units to discover the breadth of options available.

The level of the unit is indicated by the first number in the unit code; undergraduate units are those that commence with the numbers 1-3. You may need permission from the owning faculty to enrol in some units taught by other faculties.

requirement_groups.title: APAC  - Psychology extended  major
requirement_groups.description:
The Psychology extended major (APAC accredited level 1 sequence of units) is only offered in the single degree Bachelor of Arts (A2000) or in the double degree Bachelor of Science and Bachelor of Arts (S2006).

If you are completing the Psychology extended major (APAC accredited level 1 sequence of units) below you will be required to complete 60 credit points of Psychology units and 36 credit points of Arts units which must include Arts electives (12 credit points) and Professional Futures domain units (24 credit points).

requirement_groups.title: European languages extended major
requirement_groups.description: You have the option of reaching proficient level in two European Languages by completing an extended major. You must begin at entry level 2 intermediate level in at least one of the two languages.

requirement_groups.title: Part A. Arts listed majors and extended major
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete one of the following majors including:

- a maximum of 12 credit points at Level 1 and,
- a minimum of 18 credit points at Level 3.

It is recommended thatyou complete Level 2 units in more than one area of arts to give options for finalisingyour choice of major at Level 3.

If you are planning to take the Economics major, please note that background knowledge and application of maths is required at the equivalent of VCE Year 12 Higher level. You may have satisfied this by completing relevant prerequisite unit/s, or by studying relevant topics in your final years of secondary school or by successfully completing either ECC1550 Introduction to quantitative skills for social sciences or MTH1010 Functions and their applications, as a first-year elective.

requirement_groups.title: A2001 - Complete Requirements
requirement_groups.description: Complete all requirements for Bachelor of Global Studies

requirement_groups.title: Part C. Free elective study
requirement_groups.description:
Elective units may be chosen from the faculty or across the University as long as you have the prerequisites and there are no restrictions on admission to the units. Further units from Part B are recommended. The units may be at any level, however, no more than 60 credit points at Level 1 can be credited to the Bachelor of Global Studies.

You can also use this space to refine your academic and professional skills with an internship or a range of practical units. See Arts enrichment and Monash Intercultural Lab list of units to discover the breadth of options available.

The level of the unit is indicated by the first number in the unit code; undergraduate units are those that commence with the numbers 1-3. You may need permission from the owning faculty to enrol in some units taught by other faculties.

If you are in a double degree course, some units required for the other degree are credited as electives towards the global studies degree.

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description:
To satisfy the requirements of the Bachelor of Global Studies you must complete 144 credit points as specified in the course requirements, including:

- a maximum of 60 credit points at Level 1 and,
- a minimum of 36 credit points at Level 3 from Part A and B.

requirement_groups.title: Culture and identity
requirement_groups.description: Explore how social identities are formed through global circulation of cultural beliefs and practices. Understand the role of culture in creating meaningful, and sometimes contested, worldviews.

requirement_groups.title: Social justice
requirement_groups.description: Tackle critical issues of power, and inequality through an exploration of historical and contemporary struggles against racism, colonialism, and economic disparity. Understand the roots of injustice and contribute to a more equitable world.

requirement_groups.title: Global communication
requirement_groups.description: Understand how language shapes our engagement with a diverse and interconnected world. Develop the strategies and skills of communication needed to thrive in internationalised workplaces.

requirement_groups.title: Research pathway
requirement_groups.description: This unit is recommended if you are interested in pursuing research related to global studies after graduating.

requirement_groups.title: Sustainability
requirement_groups.description: Explore global environmental challenges and solutions through units on climate history, urban sustainability, and the intersection of climate change with social justice. Evaluate the past, understand the present, and design a sustainable future for our planet.

requirement_groups.title: Part B. Global studies specialist knowledge
requirement_groups.description: You must complete 30 credit points chosen from one or more specialist knowledge areas listed below, with at least 18 points at level 3. You may also take units in Part A not already completed including further language and global mobility units.

Part D. Free electives
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 48 credit points of free elective study. Free elective units in all specialisations enable you to further your knowledge of your specialisation or media communication more broadly. Units from the elective lists for the specialisations in this course are recommended, as are any remaining cornerstone or capstone units from any of the specialisations.

You can enrich your degree by using some of your free electives to take a study tour, field trip or exchange opportunity. You can also use this space to hone your academic and professional skills with an internship or a range of practical units. SeeArts enrichmentandMonash Intercultural Lablist of units to discover the breadth of options available.

Elective units may be chosen from the faculty or across the University as long as you have the prerequisites and there are no restrictions on admission to the units. You may need permission from the owning faculty to enrol in some units taught by other faculties. The units may be at any level ensuring that the course rules are satisfied for the Bachelor of Media Communication.

The level of the unit is indicated by the first number in the unit code; undergraduate units are those that commence with the numbers 1-3.

If you are in a double degree course, some units required for the other degree are credited as electives towards the media communications specialist degree.

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description:
To satisfy the requirements of the Bachelor of Media Communication you must complete 144 credit points as specified in the course requirements, including:

-a maximum of 60 credit points at Level 1 and,
-a minimum of 36 credit points at Level 3, of which at least 24 credit points must be from the specialisation.

It is recommended that you complete Level 1 sequences first as these lay the foundation for further study. Gateway units (24 credit points) must be chosen from two specialisations in the first year of study.

You are required to nominate your chosen specialisation at the end of your first year of study.

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description:
To satisfy the requirements of the Bachelor of Music you must complete 144 credit points as specified in the course requirements, including:

- a maximum of 60 credit points at Level 1 and,
- a minimum of 24 credit points must be completed in music at Level 3.

requirement_groups.title: Part B. Music theory and ear training
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete the following units.

Note 1: If you are a BMus or a BMus double degree student, you may choose to take an examination at the commencement of ATS1899 Music theory and ear training 1. If you pass, you may be granted an exemption from this unit and be allowed to enrol in ATS1347 Ensemble studies 1 or another approved unit. Similarly, you may be exempted from ATS1900Music theory and ear training 2 if at the commencement of this unit you choose to take an examination and pass it. This will allowyou to enrol in ATS1348 Ensemble studies 2 or another approved unit.

Note 2: If you are completing Popular music you may replace ATS2901Music theoryand ear training 3 andATS2902Musictheoryand ear training 4 with the elective units ATS2159 Recording and computer music production and ATS2139Song writing: How to write a popular song.

requirement_groups.title: Part A. Music specialist study
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete one specialisation from the following.

To avoid exceeding the standard three year course duration you must enrol in the music specialist study 1 and 2 units in your first year of study, then progress to the music specialist study 3 to 6 units in the following years. You must pass each unit sequentially.

requirement_groups.title: Part D. Free elective study
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 48 credit points of free elective study. You may select any units from Part C. Music context study, as listed above. or any units from the music electives listed below as long as you are eligible to enrol in the particular units. .

You can enrich your degree by using some of your free electives to take a study tour, field trip or exchange opportunity. You can also use this space to hone your academic and professional skills with an internship or a range of practical units. SeeArts enrichmentandMonash Intercultural Lablist of units to discover the breadth of options available.

In addition, you may choose units from across the Arts faculty, or from across the University (including a major or minor from another course) as long as you have the prerequisites and there are no restrictions on admission to the units. You may need permission from the owning faculty to enrol in some units taught by other faculties. The units may be at any level ensuring that the course rules are satisfied for the Bachelor of Music.

The level of the unit is indicated by the first number in the unit code; undergraduate units are those that commence with the numbers 1-3. You may need permission from the owning faculty to enrol in some units taught by other faculties.

If you are in a double degree course, some units required for the other degree are credited as electives towards the music degree.

requirement_groups.title: Part C. Free elective study
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 48 credit points of free elective study. Elective units may be chosen from units available in the Bachelor of Arts and Social Sciences course including to extend your major or to complete a second major or minor(s) from the course. Note that, at most, two units may be counted towards two majors or a major and a minor.

Elective units may also be taken from non-arts disciplines to broaden your knowledge or to complete a major or minor(s) from another course as long as you have the prerequisites and there are no restrictions on enrolment in the units. The units may be at any level ensuring that the course rules are satisfied for the Bachelor of Arts and Social Sciences.

The level of the unit is indicated by the first number in the unit code; undergraduate units are those that commence with the numbers 1-3. You may need permission from the owning faculty to enrol in some units taught by other faculties.

requirement_groups.title: Part B. Arts and social sciences listed major
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete at least one Arts and Social Sciences listed major. You may replace the major with an extended major by using the elective units available in Part A or Part C.

Note: Psychology is taught by the Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences.

If you are intending to undertake an honours year you should ensure you complete the specific units required as a pre-requisite for honours in your major area of study.

requirement_groups.title: Option 1
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete an Arts and Social Sciences listed minor from the following list plus an additional four units selected from those listed under any major, extended major or minor offered in the Bachelor of Arts and Social Sciences, with at least one unit at Level 3.

It is recommended that you complete Level 1 units in more than two areas of arts and social sciences to give you options for finalising your choice of major and minor.

requirement_groups.title: Option 2
requirement_groups.description: You may replace the minor and the 24 credit points of elective units from Option 1 with a second arts and social sciences major from the following list

requirement_groups.title: Part A. Arts and social sciences specified study
requirement_groups.description: You must complete one of the following options

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description:
To satisfy the requirements of the Bachelor of Arts and Social Sciences you must complete 144 credit points as specified in the course requirements, including:

-a maximum of 60 credit points at Level 1 and,
-a minimum of 36 credit points at Level 3, or which at least 24 credit points must be Arts units.

It is recommended that you keep your options open in your first year by taking a sequence of units in at least two different areas of study that offer majors within arts and social sciences.

Elective units can be at any level unless otherwise specified.

requirement_groups.title: A2008 - Complete Requirements
requirement_groups.description: Complete all requirements for Bachelor of Criminology

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description:
To satisfy the requirements of the the Bachelor of Criminology you must complete 144 credit points as specified in the course requirements, including:

- a maximum of 60 credit points at Level 1 and,
-a minimum of 36 credit points at Level 3, of which at least 24 credit points must be from criminology.

requirement_groups.title: Part D. Free electives
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 48 credit points of free elective study.

Units from the criminology elective list in this course are recommended as they enable you to further your knowledge criminology more broadly. You can enrich your degree by using some of your free electives to take a study tour, field trip or exchange opportunity. You can also use this space to hone your academic and professional skills with an internship or a range of practical units. See Arts enrichment and Monash Intercultural Lab list of units to discover the breadth of options available.

Elective units may be chosen from the faculty or across the University as long as you have the prerequisites and there are no restrictions on admission to the units. The units may be at any level ensuring that the course rules are satisfied for the Bachelor of Criminology.

Free electives can be identified using the browse units tool and indexes of units in the current edition of the Handbook. The level of the unit is indicated by the first number in the unit code; undergraduate units are those that commence with the numbers 1-3. You may need permission from the owning faculty to enrol in some units taught by other faculties.

If you are enrolled in a double degree course, some units required for the other degree are credited as electives towards the criminology degree.

You can also use your free electives for study tours, field trips, internships, exchange opportunities or explore the Arts enrichment and Monash Intercultural Lab for other available options.

requirement_groups.title: Part D. Free elective study
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 48 credit points of free elective study.

Elective units may be chosen from the school or across the University as long as you have the prerequisites and there are no restrictions on admission to the units. The units may be at any level, however, no more than 60 credit points at Level 1 can be credited to the Bachelor of Digital Media and Communication.

You may opt to exchange some or all of the electives to pursue a minor (24 credit points) or major (48 credit points) in another Arts discipline (Global studies, Gender studies, Film and TV studies or Writing), or another school (IT, Businessor Psychology). A minor would replace 24 credit points of your electives, while a major would replace all (48 credit points) of your electives.

Free electives can be identified using the Advanced search tool in the current edition of the Handbook. The level of the unit is indicated by the first number in the unit code; undergraduate units are those that commence with the numbers 1-3. You may need permission from the owning faculty to enrol in some units taught by other faculties.

The Advanced search tool can also be used to search and identify majors and minors offered at Malaysia.

If you are enrolled in a double degree course, please note that some of the units required for the other degree are credited as electives towards the Digital Media and Communication degree.

requirement_groups.title: Part B. Specialist knowledge
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 24 credit points, with at least 12 credit points at Level 3, chosen from one or more elective streams listed below.

You may also choose to complete units not already completed in Part A.

requirement_groups.title: Part C. Free electives
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 48 credit points of free elective study. Units from the discipline elective list in this course are recommended as they will enable you to further your knowledge in international relations more broadly.

You can use free electives to broaden your university experience and consolidate your learning by undertaking a study tour, field trip, exchange opportunity or practical units. See Arts enrichment and Monash Intercultural Lab list of units to discover the breadth of options available.

Elective units may be chosen from the faculty or across the University as long as you have the prerequisites and there are no restrictions on admission to the units. The units may be at any level ensuring that the course rules are satisfied for the Bachelor of International Relations.

Free electives can be identified using the browse units tool and indexes of units in the current edition of the Handbook. The level of the unit is indicated by the first number in the unit code; undergraduate units are those that commence with the numbers 1-3. You may need permission from the owning faculty to enrol in some units taught by other faculties.

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description:
The course comprises 144 credit points, of which 96 credit points are international relations and 48 credit points are free electives, structured in three parts Part A. Foundational knowledge (72 credit points), Part B. Specialist knowledge (24 credit points) and Part C. Free Electives (48 credit points).

To satisfy the requirements of the Bachelor of International Relations you must complete 144 credit points as specified in the course requirements, including:

-a maximum of 60 credit points at level 1 and,
-a minimum of 36 credit points must be completed at level 3.

requirement_groups.title: Year two - Part B. Exchange studies
requirement_groups.description:
Following the successful completion of 48 credit points toward the Master of Journalism, you will then travel to the University of Warwick. You will follow your choice of one of the Master of Arts programs offered through PAIS at Warwick, which includes a 40 CATS (credit) core module and 80 CATS of optional modules.

While at Warwick you will be enrolled in the following Monash units (48 credit points).

requirement_groups.title: Students studying the double degree
requirement_groups.description:
If you are in the double degree course you complete a total of 120 credit points across Monash and Warwick University. This includes, Part A. Monash Journalism studies (48 credit points) of the Monash course, and Part B. Exchange studies (48 credit points) of the Master of Arts degree at Warwick.

For the final 24 credit points of the Monash course you complete a research thesis (24 credit points). This will be a joint dissertation of 15,000 words in total or an equivalent journalism research project which is jointly supervised by one academic from Warwick and one academic from Monash and is jointly examined by both partner universities.

requirement_groups.title: Year Three - Part C. Research project
requirement_groups.description: On completion of the coursework component of one of the Master of Arts programs offered through PAIS at Warwick, you will either remain a further semester/term at Warwick, or return to Monash, and will complete a joint dissertation of 15 000 words in total or an equivalent journalism research project (24 credit points), which is jointly supervised by one academic from Warwick and one academic from Monash.

requirement_groups.title: Information for Monash and SJTU students
requirement_groups.description:
Monash students will normally commence the first year at Monash (in July), and the second year at SJTU.

Following completion of the academic program at Monash comprising 48 credit points (one year full-time) of study towards the Master of Strategic Communications Management, selected students will travel to China to complete a further 48 credit points (one year full-time) study toward theMaster of Journalism and Communication from Shanghai Jiao Tong University (SJTU). The thesis will take place at the end of the second year at SJTU (normally around early June).

SJTU students will normally commence the first year at SJTU, and the second year at Monash (July). They will then return to SJTU to complete the requirements of the thesis.

requirement_groups.title: Part B. Business listed major
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete at least one major from the list below. The major will comprise 42 credit points from Part B and 6 credit points from Part A (related unit from business specified study) to total 48 credit points which is required to equal a major.

If you are intending to undertake an honours year, you should ensure you complete the specific units required for honours in your chosen major area of study.

No more than 12 credit points can be credited towards two majors, or a major and a minor, within a course. The same credit points cannot be credited towards more than one minor.

Students completing the double degree D3007 Bachelor of Education (Honours) and Bachelor of Business, who are in the Secondary Education specialisation, must qualify for two separate specialist areas. Please refer to the Notes to see which secondary specialist teaching areas are available by Course.

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description: In choosingyour units,you must ensure thatyou complete no more than 10 units (60 credit points) at Level 1 and at leastsix units (36 credit points) at Level 3, including four units (24 credit points) at Level 3 offered by the Faculty of Business and Economics.

requirement_groups.title: Part C. Free elective study
requirement_groups.description:
Electives can be chosen from within the Bachelor of Business, including units to complete a second major or minor(s).

Enrolment in Faculty of Business and Economics units at campuses other than the campus of enrolment is subject to there being capacity after students from that campus have enrolled. Electives can also be chosen from across the University, including completing a major or minor from another course if you have met the required prerequisites and there are no restrictions on enrolling in the units. You should also be aware of travel and timetabling limitations.

If you are in a double degree course, some units required for the other degree are credited as electives towards this Business degree.

You can enrich your degree to hone your academic and professional skills with a range of Flagship Rich Educational Experiences (FREE), including the Research, Experimentation and Discovery, Monash Innovation Guarantee, Global Immersion Guarantee, or Volunteering if not already completed as an Integrating Unit in Part A. These flagship rich educational experience units may be credited utilising your free electives if approved by the faculty. There are both 6 and 12 credit point unit options available.

requirement_groups.title: Capstone, project, international or internship experience unit
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete one unit from one of the following lists unless you are undertaking the Bachelor of Education (Honours) in Secondary Education and Bachelor of Business (course D3007) or completing a major in Accounting. If you are undertaking D3007, EDF4068 Teaching performance assessment meets this requirement, and you are required to choose another 6 credit point unit from the Accounting, Business law, Business management or Economics and business strategy majors. If you are completing a major in Accounting and seeking professional accounting accreditation you will need to complete ACX3900. You can undertake more than one unit from the following lists, which will count towards your electives.

If you choose a 12 or 24 credit point unit you will need to reduce the amount of points available for free electives in Part C which may impact on the ability to complete a major using electives.

requirement_groups.title: Integrating unit
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete one of the following units, unless you are undertaking the Bachelor of Education (Honours) in Secondary Education and Bachelor of Business (course D3007).

If you are undertaking this course, EDF2078 Creative and critical teaching meets this requirement, and you are required to choose another 6 credit point unit from the Accounting, Business law, Business management or Economics and business strategy majors.

If you choose a 12 credit point unit you will need to reduce the amount of points available for free electives in Part C by 6 credit points, which may impact onthe ability to complete a major using electives.

Note: If you are enrolled in a double degree it may be possible to do the Global Immersion Guarantee (12 credit points). For information on eligible double degree combinations please see Global Immersion Guarantee.

requirement_groups.title: Part A. Business administration specified study
Part B. Business administration listed major
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete at least one business-listed major from the Peninsula campus. A major consists of eight units with no more than two units (12 credit points) at Level 1 credited to the major and at least three units (18 credit points) at Level 3 credited to the major.

No more than 12 credit points can be credited towards two majors, or a major and a minor, within a course. The same credit points cannot be credited towards more than one minor.

Depending on the major you choose, you may have already studied one of the required units as part of your business specified study. If so, you must complete an additional business unit offered at the Peninsula campus.

If you are intending to undertake an honours year, you should ensure you complete the specific units required for honours in your chosen major area of study.

requirement_groups.title: Part C. Free elective study

You can choose electives from within the Bachelor of Business Administration, including units to complete a second major or minor(s). Enrolment in Faculty of Business and Economics units at campuses other than your campus of enrolment is subject to there being spare capacity after students from that campus have enrolled.

You can also choose electives from across the University, including to complete a major or minor from another course if you have met the required prerequisites and there are no restrictions on enrolling in the units. You should also be aware of travel and timetabling limitations.

Note. ECX3550 and ETB2111 are offered at Peninsula.

You can enrich your degree to hone your academic and professional skills with a range of Flagship Rich Educational Experiences (FREE), including the Research, Experimentation and Discovery, Monash Innovation Guarantee and Global Immersion Guarantee. These flagship rich educational experience units may be credited utilising your free electives if approved by the faculty. There are both 6 and 12 credit point unit options available.

Where you have space in your degree you may complete a second major with no more than two units contributing towards both of your chosen majors or towards both a major and the specialisation.

Where there is double up of units across the two single degrees, these units must be replaced by another unit. Up to six of these may be replaced by a unit from across the University, providing the prerequisites are met and there are no restrictions on admission to the units. You may also be able to use these replacement units to take a 12 or 24 credit point project, international experience or internship, or undertake a minor in a different discipline from your major.

No more than two units can contribute towards two majors, or a major and a minor, in the same course (including a double degree course). The same unit is not credited towards two minors.

Students who chose the Actuarial analytics specialisation can utilise the free electives to do the remaining actuarial exemption units from Part C to maximise their future career options.

You must ensure that you complete at least six units (36 credit points) at Level 3 in this course. If you take less than six Level 3 units in total under Part B and C you must take additional Level 3 units in Part D such that the total number of Level 3 units is at least six.

Electives can also be chosen from across the University, including to complete a major or minor from another course if you have met the required prerequisites and there are no restrictions on enrolling in the units. Enrolment in Faculty of Business and Economics units at campuses other than the campus of enrolment is subject to there being capacity after students from that campus have enrolled. You should be aware of travel and timetabling limitations.

No more than two units can contribute towards two majors, or a major and a minor, in the same course (including a double degree course). The same unit is not credited towards two minors. For studentsin a double degree course, some units required for the other degree are credited as electives towards this Actuarial Science degree.

You can enrich your degree to hone your academic and professional skills with a range of Flagship Rich Educational Experiences (FREE), including the Research, Experimentation and Discovery, Monash Innovation Guarantee and Global Immersion Guarantee. These flagship rich educational experience units may be credited utilising your free electives if approved by their faculty.

You can enrich your degree by honing your academic and professional skills through the Monash Innovation Guarantee (MIG). The MIG is your unique opportunity to collaborate with renowned industry leaders and design innovative solutions that result in real social change. MIG will give you the leadership skills you will need to adapt and thrive in a rapidly changing world and is your chance to make connections before you graduate. The MIG unit may be credited in place of a free elective as a 6 credit point unit option. For information on eligibility please see FREE.

requirement_groups.title: Part C. Electives
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete four elective units (24 credit points) which may include units not already completed in Part B, or you may choose up to two units from the list below or you may choose any units at Level 4 or 5 from the Faculty of Business and Economics, which could include study tours, consulting projects or industry placements. In addition units may be selected from across the University as long as you have met the prerequisites and there are no restrictions on enrolling in the units.

You can enrich your degree by honing your academic and professional skills through the Monash Innovation Guarantee (MIG). The MIG is your unique opportunity to collaborate with renowned industry leaders and design innovative solutions that result in real social change. MIG will give you the leadership skills you will need to adapt and thrive in a rapidly changing world and is your chance to make connections before you graduate. The MIG unit may be credited in place of a free elective as a 6 credit point unit option. For information on eligibility please see FREE.

The Course Director can guide you to appropriate electives based on your area of interest.

requirement_groups.title: Part C. Advanced discipline knowledge

requirement_groups.title: Free electives
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 24 credit points of units.

You must complete at least six units (36 credit points) at Level 3 in this course. If you take less than six Level 3 units in total under Part B and Part C, you must take additional Level 3 units in Part D. Electives can also be chosen from across the University, including to complete a major or minor from another course if you have met the required prerequisites and there are no restrictions on enrolling in the units. Enrolment in Faculty of Business and Economics units at campuses other than the campus of enrolment is subject to there being capacity after students from that campus have enrolled. You should also be aware of travel and timetabling limitations.

No more than two units can contribute towards two majors, or a major and a minor, in the same course (including a double degree course). The same unit is not credited towards two minors.

Electives can be identified using the advanced search in the current edition of the Handbook. Majors and minors can be identified using the Handbook advanced search. The level of the unit is indicated by the first number in the unit code; undergraduate units are those that commence with the numbers 1-3.

You can enrich your degree to hone your academic and professional skills with a range of flagship rich experiences, including the Research, Experimentation and Discovery, Monash Immersion Guarantee, Global Immersion Guarantee or Volunteering. These flagship rich experience units may be credited in place of your free electives if approved by the faculty. There are both 6 and 12 credit point unit options available.

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description:
In choosing units you must ensure that you complete no more than 10 Level one units (60 credit points), and at least six units (36 credit points) at Level 3 of which at least four (24 credit points) are Bachelor of Information Technology listed (FIT-coded) units.

Note: If you are in a double degree with the Bachelor of Information Technology, no more than 36 credit points can be completed at Level 1.

requirement_groups.title: Part B. Information Technology listed major
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete at least one of the following Information Technology listed majors.

A major requires eight units with no more than two units at Level one (12 credit points) and at least three units (18 credit points) at Level three.

requirement_groups.title: Part C. Free elective study
requirement_groups.description:
Note 1: Your elective units may be chosen from any of the units offered at Monash to suit your interests or career aspirations. You may choose to take other units available in the Bachelor of Information Technology course to extend your major or to complete a second major or minor(s) from the course, or you may take Faculty of IT units from C2001 Bachelor of Computer Science, its data science specialisation, or the software engineering specialisation in the Bachelor of Engineering (Honours). Elective units may also be used to sample from across the University or to complete a major or minor(s) from another course aslong asyou have completedthe prerequisites and there are no restrictions on enrolment in the units.

Note 2: If you are in a double degree course, some units required for the partner degree are credited as electives towards this degree.

requirement_groups.description: You must complete the following units

requirement_groups.title: Games and immersive media major
requirement_groups.description: You must complete the following units

requirement_groups.title: Industry-based learning placement stream
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete the following unit.

Note: If you are selected to participate in the IBL placement program you will complete FIT3045 Industry-based learning placement (18 credit points) and FIT2108 Industry-based learning onboarding (0 points) which will replace the capstone project units and the nominated Level 3 unit in the major.

In the IBL program you must complete a unit over summer semester or overload in one semester by one unit in order to complete the degree within three years (this is because you only complete 18 credit points of credit during the IBL placement semester). You must have completed at least three semesters of your course before starting your IBL placement.

requirement_groups.description: You must complete the following units

requirement_groups.title: Capstone project units
requirement_groups.description: You must complete the capstone project units (12 points) (as applicable to your chosen major); or the industry-based learning placement units (18 points); or the work professional placement unit (18 points) .

requirement_groups.description: You must complete one of the following units

requirement_groups.title: Industry based learning
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete one of the following units.

FIT3045 is only available if you are selected to participate in the IBL placement program. You will replace the Level 3 elective unit (6 credit points) from your specialisation: Advanced computer science or Data science, to make up the 18 credit points required. You must complete one unit over summer semester or overload in one semester by one unit in order to complete the degree within three years.

FIT3199 must be completed over the summer vacation period between second and third year. This unit will provide a framework for all undergraduate information technology students at the Malaysia campus to complete the compulsory industry experience as required by the Malaysian Qualifications Agency.

requirement_groups.title: Malaysia option
requirement_groups.description:
Students at the Malaysia campus are required to have completed an industry placement in order to graduate. This can either be the Industry based learning unit or a zero credit point unit FIT3199 Industry work experience.

Therefore, you must complete either the Computer science project or Data science project and either FIT3045 IBL placement or FIT3199 Industry work experience.

requirement_groups.title: Industry based learning
requirement_groups.description: This option is available only if you are selected to participate in the IBL placement program. FIT3045 (18 credit points) replaces the capstone project units and the Level 3 elective unit in your specialisation. You must complete one unit over summer semester or overload in one semester by one unit in order to complete the degree within three years.

requirement_groups.title: Part D Complementary studies
requirement_groups.description:
The identified elective units complement the broad range of skills and knowledge employed by Educational Designers. Some units may have enrolment rules such as pre-requisites and you may need permission from the owning faculty to enrol in some units taught by other faculties.

The level of the unit is indicated by the first number in the unit code; undergraduate units are those that commence with the numbers 1-3. If you wish to pursue an alternative elective unit, you will need to seek the approval of the Faculty of Education.

You can enrich your degree by honing your academic and professional skills through a range of flagship rich educational experiences (FREE), including the Monash Innovation Guarantee. These FREE units may be credited in place of your free electives if approved by the faculty. You must discuss your eligibility with your Education Success Adviser (ESA) prior to enrolling in FREE. There are both 6 and 12 credit point unit options available.

From the following elective unit selections, you must complete 30 points of which no more than 12 points are at level 1:

requirement_groups.title: Arts component
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 96 credit points comprising all the requirements from Parts A and B as described in the Bachelor of Arts degree.
No more than 36 credit points can be completed at Level 1. At least 24 credit points must be completed at Level 3.

For Part B Arts Specified Study, you must complete 12 credit points of units from the Professional Futures domains and the remaining 12 credit points should be selected from Level 1, 2 or 3 Arts' elective units.

For your discipline studies in the double degree secondary education specialisation, you must complete a Victorian Institute of Teaching minor study in one secondary teaching area. The minor study must consist of four units, with no more than two units at first year level. Space for the minor study units will come from elective unit allocations on the course map. Approved disciplines can be found on the secondary specialist areas page: https://www.monash.edu/education/students/courses/units/secondary-specialisms

In selecting your Science studies, you must take note of the specialisms required for teaching. Students in the Secondary Education specialisation must qualify for two separate specialist teaching areas. The Secondary specialist areas available by course (https://www.monash.edu/education/students/courses/units/secondary-specialisms) shows which secondary teaching areas are available. You must complete the mathematics and statistics unit requirement within the first 72 credit points of this double degree course

The psychology extended major is not available in this double degree.

requirement_groups.title: Option 2 - Pathway to graduate research
requirement_groups.description:
A pathway to graduate research (e.g. master by research, PhD) is available if you have been admitted at level 1 or level 2 and have achieved a weighted average mark of at least 75% in the units of this course.

This pathway is only available to students enrolled at Clayton, and is not available at the point of course entry; if you wish to complete the research pathway units, you must enrol in the units below. Students eligibility will be checked prior to the commencement of EDF5613.

If you are commencing at entry level 1 or 2, you must take the required two units in Part C of your studies.

Due to professional recognition requirements, the research pathway is not available if you have been admitted at level 3. If you have been admitted at level 3 and are interested in a research pathway you are encouraged to consider the Graduate Certificate of Educational Research.

requirement_groups.title: Pathway to graduate research (optional)
requirement_groups.description:
A pathway to graduate research (e.g. master's by research, PhD) is available if you: have been admitted at level 1 or 2; and achieve a weighted average mark (WAM) of at least 75% in the units of this course.

If you are completing this pathway, you will need to make the following unit substitutions: EDF5613 Research approaches in education (12 credit points) to replace EDF5690 Educational leadership inquiry (12 credit points) (Part B); EDF5614 Research project in education (12 credit points) to replace 12 credit points of approved Level 5 units from select Faculty of Education graduate coursework programs (Part C).

Please note: This pathway is not available at the point of entry; your eligibility to undertake this pathway will be checked prior to the commencement of EDF5613; if you are commencing at entry level 1 or 2, you must take the required two units in the final semester of your studies; and the research pathway is not available if you have been admitted at level 3. If you have been admitted at level 3 and are interested in a research pathway you are encouraged to consider the Graduate Certificate of Educational Research.

requirement_groups.title: Engineering minors
requirement_groups.description:
An engineering minor will diversify your skill set and add versatility. If you are enrolled in the engineering single degree course, you can use your engineering electives in Years 2, 3 and 4 to complete a minor from a different engineering discipline.

While most specialisations have complementary combinations with minors, it should be noted that the Biomedical Engineering and Software Engineering specialisations currently do not offer any options to pursue a minor. Minors are also not available in the engineering double-degrees.

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description:
The course comprises 192 credit points, of which 144 credit points are from core engineering study and 48 credit points are available for elective study.

- No more than 60 credit points of Level 1 units can be credited to the engineering course.
- A minimum of 72 credit points must be completed in engineering studies at Levels 3, 4 or 5.

You must satisfy the continuous professional development requirements (See ENG0001 or ENG0002).

requirement_groups.title: Part B. Engineering design
requirement_groups.description: You must complete the following units

requirement_groups.title: Engineering double-degree
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete one unit (6 credit points) chosen from the First Year engineering breadth study list.

If you are required to complete foundational study, the foundation unit is undertaken in place of the First Year engineering breadth unit. If you require both foundation units, the second foundation unit will increase your total credit points needed for the double degree by 6 credit points. A study overload will occur in Year 1 or 2.

requirement_groups.title: Engineering single degree
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete one unit (6 credit points) chosen from the First Year engineering breadth study list AND two electives (12 credit points).

You must complete foundational study, if required. If no foundational study is required, you may choose to select your electives from the First Year engineering breadth study list or from across the University, subject to meeting the unit enrolment rules.

requirement_groups.title: First Year engineering breadth study list
requirement_groups.description:
Note 1. Biomedical engineering: If you intend to specialise in biomedical engineering, you must select and complete BMS1021.

Note 2. Chemical engineering:Due to the prohibition with CHE2161, you are strongly advised against completing MEC2404 as a First Year elective. This choice may result in an inadequate foundation for the subsequent core unit CHE3167 in the chemical engineering specialisation.

Note 3. Software engineering: If you intend to specialise in software engineering, you must select and complete FIT1045, as it provides essential grounding in programming and prepares you for advanced software engineering units.

Note 4. CHM1011 and CHM1051 are mutual prohibition units, meaning that you can only complete either CHM1011 or CHM1051.

Note 5. If you complete a First Year engineering breadth unit that happens to be a core unit in your chosen specialisation, the unit will count towards your specialisation study. You must still fulfil the First Year engineering breadth study requirement by completing another breadth study unit.

requirement_groups.title: Foundational study
requirement_groups.description:
If you have not completed either or both VCE Physics (Units 3 and 4) and VCE Specialist mathematics (Units 3 and 4) or equivalent and with the required study score, you must complete the following physics and/or mathematics foundation units.

To check the required study score, visit https://www.monash.edu/engineering/current-students/enrolment-and-re-enrolment/how-to-enrol-and-re-enrol/course-information/undergraduate-enrolment

requirement_groups.title: Master's thesis research stream
requirement_groups.description:
Enrolment in the Master's thesis research stream is subject to the availability of supervisors and projects. To be eligible, you must maintain a minimum overall Weighted Average Mark (WAM) of 65%. The selection process involves ranking eligible students based on their entire academic record and assessing their suitability for undertaking the research component of the program.

In this stream, you must complete the two thesis units below (24 credit points).

requirement_groups.title: Part C. Design studios
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 60 credit points of Design studios - this must include DGN1000 Design studio 1 (12 credit points) AND four other Studio units (12 credit points each).
You must complete the requirements for one of the specialisations - Collaborative design OR Communication design OR Industrial design OR Spatial design. Studio units 4 and 5 must be completed in your chosen specialisation.
To complete the 60 credit points for the Design studio component, you may complete ALL Studio units in your chosen specialisation, OR you may take EITHER Studio 2 OR Studio 3 from an alternative specialisation: Collaborative design OR Communication design OR Industrial design OR Spatial design.

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description: The course comprises 144 credit points, of which 96 credit points are focussed on the study of design and 48 credit points are free electives. requirement_groups.title: Part E. Non-law study
requirement_groups.description:
You may take up to four non-law units (24 credit points) provided you satisfy the unit rules.

Four units is sufficient to complete a minor in a discipline outside law which would be listed on your transcript. When selecting units to comprise a minor you should refer to the lists of minors in the arts, science, commerce, business and information technology comprehensive courses.

You may be eligible to undertake Flagship Rich Educational Experiences which can be credited towards either law or non-law electives where this can be accommodated. Note that if you are enrolled in a double degree the Global Immersion Guarantee (12 credit points) may not be available.

If you are completing a double degree course, eight units (48 credit points) required for the partner degree are credited as electives towards the law degree.

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description: You must complete 204 credit points, comprising 102 credit points of core law units and 102 credit points of electives which may include up to 24 credit points of non-law units outside the Faculty of Law or the 48 credit points of non-law units required to be cross credited towards a double degree course.

requirement_groups.title: Part D. Extending expertise: Specialist law electives
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete between thirteen and seventeen law electives which must include one commercial law elective and one law research elective.

Note: You may choose any master's level elective which a) is approved for undergraduate enrolment, and b) has as part of its assessment regime a research assignment with a word limit of 3750 words or more.

High achieving students have the opportunity of undertaking a maximum of two master's level electives in the final semester, which can be counted towards a Master of Laws (LLM) degree if they wish to progress to LLM studies.

requirement_groups.title: Elective units
requirement_groups.description:
One or two Level 2 or Level 3 elective units (6 or 12 credit points) chosen from across the Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences; those with prefixes NUT, PHY, HSC, BCH being most appropriate.

Electives may also be chosen across the University as long they are Level 2 or Level 3 and you meet the prerequisites and there are no restrictions on enrolment in the units.

You must complete a minimum of 36 credit points of NUT units (of which 30 credit points are compulsory).

Electives can be identified using the University Handbook search tool. The level of the unit is indicated by the first number in the unit code; undergraduate units are those that commence with the numbers 1-3.

You may need permission from the owning faculty to enrol in some units taught by other faculties.

requirement_groups.description: Complete all requirements for Bachelor of Biomedical Science

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description: To remain in the scholars program, you must maintain at least a distinction average (70%) across 48 credit points in each calendar year.

requirement_groups.title: Scholars program
requirement_groups.description: If you are in the scholars program you are required to include at least one of the following units in your choice of electives

requirement_groups.title: Part B. Free elective study
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 48 credit points of free elective study.

Elective units can be chosen from across the Faculty and used to deepen your knowledge of the biomedical sciences. This includes those with the prefixes BCH, BME, DEV, GEN, HUP, IMM, MIC, MIS, NUT, PHA and PHY (please note that some of these are prohibited with core BMS units).

Elective units may also be used to sample disciplines from across the University provided you have met the required prerequisites and there are no restrictions on enrolment into the units. The faculties of Arts, Business and Economics, Engineering, Information Technology and Science offer units particularly suitable as electives.
Electives may be from any level, however, no more than four electives (24 credit points) are to be completed from level 1 and at least two electives (12 credit points) must be completed at Level 3.

Your free electives may be used to study a major (48 credit points) or minor (24 credit points) in a non-biomedical science discipline. This is an optional component of the degree. You cannot do a major or minor in the areas of Biochemistry, Anatomy and developmental biology, Genetics and genomics, Human pathology, Immunology, Microbiology, Pharmacology or Physiology, but you may do individual units from these areas.

requirement_groups.title: Part C. Free elective study
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 48 credit points of electives chosen from across the faculty or from any discipline across the University (including to complete a minor from another course), as long as you have the required prerequisites, co-requisites and meet any other restrictions. You may need permission from the owning faculty to enrol in some units taught by other faculties. You should also be aware of travel and timetabling limitations.

Electives must be undergraduate units, and no more than four Level 1 elective units (24 credit points) may be completed. Undergraduate units have codes which commence with the numbers 1-3, for example XXX1234, XXX2234,XXX3234. The level of the unit is indicated by the first number in the unit code.

IMPORTANT NOTE: For students who are enrolled in the double degree Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Health Sciences (A2017), 48 credit points worth of units are cross credited from the Bachelor of Arts towards the Bachelor of Health Sciences to fulfil the required Part C electives.

- Philosophy (e.g. ATS1057, ATS1835)
- Sociology (eg. ATS1365, ATS1366)

- Physiology (e.g. PHY2032, PHY2042)
- Health sciences (e.g. BMA1011, BMA1012, HSC1100, HSC1200, HSC1300, HSC1400)
- Public health (e.g. PBH1102, PBH1104, PBH2002, PBH2003, HSC2400)
- Social work (e.g. SWM3127)

However, the units you are unable to complete can be completed after graduation or via professional body courses.

requirement_groups.title: Coursework stream
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 48 credit points from one of the following specialisations (continuing the same specialisation as chosen in Part A).

NOTES:
- Some of the elective units listed within the specialisations may require on-campus participation. Please check the units handbook entry to ensure that it suits your preferred study mode. Units which have on-campus requirements are not suitable for students wishing to study fully online.
- Some of the units listed within the specialisations may be intensive online units delivered over 6 weeks. Please refer to the unit's handbook entry for expected workload requirements. Requirements for intensive unit may not align with units delivered over a standard academic semester.
- You may complete approved assessed short courses in place of elective units and apply for unspecified credit towards the elective credit point allocation. Credit limits apply, you must contact the course coordinator before enrolling in short courses. A list of approved short courses is available at the following webpage: https://www.monash.edu/medicine/spahc/study/master-of-advanced-health-care-practice/_nocache
- If you are enrolled in the Paramedicine specialisation the coursework stream is not available, you must take the research stream option 1 minor thesis.

requirement_groups.title: Option 2 - Research project
requirement_groups.description: You must complete the following units

requirement_groups.title: Research stream
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete either: Option 1 - Minor thesis, or Option 2 - Research project.

Note: Research topics will focus on the relevant specialisation.

requirement_groups.title: Part B. Advanced specialist study
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete either the Research stream or the Coursework stream as detailed below.

Notes:
If you are enrolled in the Occupational therapy specialisation, you may choose either the coursework stream OR option 2 of the research stream. Research option 1 minor thesis is not available.
If you are enrolled in the Paramedicine specialisation, the coursework stream is not available. You must complete the research stream option 1 minor thesis only. Option 2 research project is not available.

requirement_groups.title: Part B. Applied ultrasound practice
requirement_groups.description:
Prior to admission to the applied ultrasound practice units (after completion of SON4000 and SON4010), applicants must provide evidence verifying that they are actively engaged in supervised clinical ultrasound practice for the equivalent of at least three days a week. The majority of units within this course are clinically based and you must find yourself a placement as a trainee sonographer. The University does not assist with this process. You need a placement as a trainee sonographer in order to gain the experience that is required to be competent in each of the study areas. We do not recommend that candidates apply for the course unless they are certain that they can secure a clinical placement.

You must complete the following units.

all_units.SON4000: Physics of medical ultrasound and instrumentation

requirement_groups.title: a. Research pathway (Research specialisation)
requirement_groups.description:
Students who successfully complete the requirements of the Research specialisation will be eligible to graduate with the Master of Public Health (Research).

The public health research project requires you to demonstrate your ability to integrate and apply public health theory, principles and practice, and research methods to a specific public health problem or issue. Consultation with the course research project coordinator is required prior to enrolment in the research project. The research project consists of a 24 credit point research project (MAP5000 and MAP5010).

You must successfully complete the following units prior to commencing MAP5000 and MAP5010:
Part A units - MPH5040, MPH5041, and MPH5213.
Part C units - MPH5200 (if you are undertaking quantitative analysis) OR MPH5215 Qualitative research methods (for students undertaking qualitative analysis).

It is highly recommended that a research project be conducted with a principal supervisor located within the School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine. Only in special circumstances will you be permitted to complete a project with a supervisor external to the school, and may include where the project would be undertaken in your current workplace and there is an experienced supervisor/researcher willing and available to supervise you.

requirement_groups.title: Coursework pathway option
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete the following unit and four units (24 credit points) from the elective list below (Clayton students must choose from the Clayton elective list and Malaysia students must choose from the Malaysia elective list).

Clayton students only (it does not apply to students in Malaysia):
Note 1: In order to be eligible for the industry placement unit, you need to have an average of at least 70% in your core biotechnology studies (Part A). If you do not meet this requirement, then you must undertake 48 credit points of units from the elective list.

Note 2: You must have a successful application with an organisation to undertake BRM5022. Training on how to write a CV and to prepare for an interview is available and you will be provided with a list of positions to apply for.

requirement_groups.title: Research pathway option
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete the following unit.

Clayton students only (it does not apply to students in Malaysia):
Note 1: In order to be eligible for the research project, you need to have an average of at least 70%in your core biotechnology studies (Part A). If you do not meet this requirement, then you must undertake 48 credit points of units from the elective list or you may exit and graduate with a Graduate Diploma of Biotechnology.

Note 2: You must have a successful application with a research group to undertake this unit. You will be provided with a list of projects to apply for.

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description:
In order to progress into the fourth year, you must complete 144 credit points (years 1-3) and achieve at least an overall distinction average (70%). If you do not meet this standard you will exit the course with the Bachelor of Pharmaceutical Science.

If you are a high achieving student admitted to the Scholars Program you are required to maintain a distinction average in each year of the course, or you will be transferred out of the Scholars Program and will not receive the program benefits or the Scholars award.

requirement_groups.title: Level 1 science sequences
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete at least two approved Level 1 sequences from the disciplines listed below. The choice of Level 1 sequences will impact your choice of Level 2 and Level 3 units and will normally lay the foundation for a related major. The two Level 1 sequences must be selected from separate disciplines and cannot have units in common.

If you are studying a single degree course, it is recommended that you take a third Level 1 sequence in the first year to increase your options for choice of major. If you are completing a double degree course you will not be able to fit in three Level 1 sequences.

requirement_groups.description: You must complete any additional Level 1 units (usually one or two) required taking the total Level 1 science listed units to 36 credit points. Level 1 science listed units are chosen from units listed under any major, extended major or minor offered in the Bachelor of Science or Level 1 mathematics and statistics units listed above or from the following units.

requirement_groups.title: Clayton students
requirement_groups.description: You must complete any additional Level 1 units (usually one or two) required taking the total Level 1 science listed units to 36 credit points. Clayton students
requirement_groups.description: You must complete the following unit

requirement_groups.title: Malaysia students
requirement_groups.description: You must complete the following unit

requirement_groups.title: STA1010 Statistical methods for science
requirement_groups.description: STA1010 Statistical methods for science is recommended if you are planning to study areas where experimental design and data analysis skills are particularly important, such as the life sciences. STA1010 requires VCE Mathematical Methods Units 3 and 4 (or equivalent), or SCI1020 or MTH1010.

requirement_groups.title: SCI1020 Introduction to statistical reasoning
requirement_groups.description: SCI1020 Introduction to statistical reasoning is recommended if you are planning to study areas where experimental design and data analysis skills are particularly important, such as the life sciences. SCI1020 is for students without a strong mathematics background.

requirement_groups.title: Information on double degree courses
requirement_groups.description:
You are exempt from completing the mathematics and statistics unit in the following double degree courses when you complete a corresponding mathematics unit in the requirements of the partner course as listed below:

B2023 Bachelor of Commerce and Bachelor of Science - ETC1000 Business and economic statistics or ETX1100 Business statistics
E3007 Bachelor of Engineering (Honours) and Bachelor of Science - ENG1005 Engineering mathematics
S2004 Bachelor of Science and Bachelor of Computer Science - MAT1841 Continuous mathematics for computer science

requirement_groups.title: SCI1022Introduction to scientific coding
requirement_groups.description: SCI1022Introduction to scientific coding is recommended if you want to gain fundamental coding skills that can be applied in a variety of scientific areas. It will be useful for data analysis, modelling of complex systems, data manipulation and visualisation in a scientific context.SCI1022requires a raw study score of at least 25 in VCE Mathematical Methods Units 3 and 4 (or equivalent) or STA1010.

requirement_groups.title: MTH1030 Techniques for modelling
requirement_groups.description:
MTH1030 Techniques for modelling is recommended/required if you have an interest in astrophysics, some streams of climate and atmospheric science, computational science, mathematics and/or physics. MTH1030 requires a raw study score of at least 30 in VCE Specialist Mathematics (or equivalent) or MTH1020.

If you have a strong mathematics background and a keen interest in the subject you could replace the unit MTH1030 with the advanced version MTH1035. You must enrol in this unit manually via the online Enrolment Amendment form.

requirement_groups.title: MTH1020 Analysis of change
requirement_groups.description: MTH1020 Analysis of change is recommended/ required if you have an interest in astrophysics, some streams of climate and atmospheric science, computational science, mathematics and/or physics. MTH1020 requires a raw study score of at least 25 in VCE Mathematical Methods (or equivalent).

requirement_groups.title: Mathematics and statistics unit
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete at least one of the following Level 1 mathematics or statistics units if not already taken as part of a Level 1 approved sequence. Please ensure that you have met the pre-requisites for your chosen Level 1 mathematics and statistics unit. For further guidance on your mathematics and statistics unit selection you can refer to the guide provided in the Structure section under Course progression map.

You must complete this requirement within the first 48 credit points of a single Science course and within the first 72 credit points of a Science combined (double degree) course. For exceptions, please see information on double degree courses below.

requirement_groups.title: Part A. Science specified study
requirement_groups.description: Although the requirements in Part A appear to exceed 48 credit points, a Level 1 sequence is typically counted towards the chosen major (Part B) and not towards this Part.

requirement_groups.title: Part C. Free elective study
requirement_groups.description:
Elective units may be chosen from the remaining units available in the Bachelor of Science course and will enable you to extend your major or to complete a second major or minor(s).

Elective units may also be taken from non-science disciplines to broaden knowledge or to complete a major or minor(s) from another course as long as you have the prerequisites and there are no restrictions on enrolment in the units.

You may need permission from the owning faculty to enrol in some units taught by other faculties.

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description:
Note 1: In choosing the 96 credit points of Bachelor of Science listed study over Part A and Part B, you must ensure thatyoucomplete six science listed units (36 credit points) at Level 1, and ten science listed units (60 credit points) at Levels 2 and 3 with a minimum of four (24 credit points) at Level 3.

Note 2: You must ensure that across the whole course, you complete no more than ten Level 1 units (60 credit points).

Note 3: To progress in the course you must complete the Level 1 sequences at stage one before enrolling in Level 2 science units.

requirement_groups.title: Science extended majors
requirement_groups.description:
You may complete a science extended major, provided you have sufficient room in your course.

You may also use free space in your course to extend your science major to form an extended major.

The Psychology extended major (APAC accredited Level 1 sequence of units) is only offered in the single degree Bachelor of Science (S2000) or in the double degree Bachelor of Science and Bachelor of Arts (S2006). The Psychology extended major (APAC accredited Level 1 sequence of units) is required if you intend to progress to honours in Psychology.

Double degree students note: Some extended majors are not available in certain double degrees, check the Availability section of each extended major.

requirement_groups.title: Science minors
requirement_groups.description:
You may complete a science listed minor provided you have enough room in your course.

Double degree students note: Some minors are not available in certain double degrees, check the Availability section of each minor.

requirement_groups.title: Part B. Science listed major
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete at least one of the following majors.

A major requires eight units with no more than two units at Level 1 (12 credit points) and at least three units (18 credit points) at Level 3. You may replace the major with an extended major by using the elective units available in Part A. or Part C.

It is recommended that you consider completing Level 2 units in more than one area of science to maximise your choice of major at Level 3.

If you are intending to undertake an honours year you should ensure that you complete the specific units required as a prerequisite for honours in your chosen major area of study.

Double degree students note: Some majors are not available in certain double degrees, check the Availability section of each major.

all_units.MTE4235: Nuclear energy: Science, technology and society
all_units.SCI2030: Indigenous science: Science through the eyes of Australias first peoples
all_units.SCI2400: Creative methods at the intersections of science and art
all_units.ENV1800: Environmental science: A Southeast Asian perspective
all_units.ATS1310: Extreme earth! The geography of disasters
all_units.EAE1022: The Earth system: Changing environments and climates
all_units.EAE1011: The Earth system: From the core to the atmosphere

You must complete 24 credit points of complementary studies from a defined discipline area listed below.

requirement_groups.title: Rules
requirement_groups.description: The course comprises 144 credit points of which 132 credit points are focused on Applied Data Science. No more than 10 units (60 credit points) are to be completed at Level 1 in the course.

requirement_groups.title: Part D. Free elective study
requirement_groups.description:
You must complete 12 credit points of free elective study.

Elective units may be chosen from the list of units from Parts B or C not already completed or from across the University as long as you have the prerequisites and there are no restrictions on admission to the units.

Free electives can be identified using the Advanced search tool in the current edition of the Handbook. The level of the unit is indicated by the first number in the unit code; undergraduate units are those that commence with the numbers 1-3.

You may need permission from the owning faculty to enrol in some units taught by other faculties.
